nodes.bodyText: The suggested change isn't grammatically correct. Can you explain the problem you were attempting to solve with this?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@ experimental[]
 
 To preserve flexibility, Rollup Jobs are defined based on how future queries may need to use the data.  Traditionally, systems force
 the admin to make decisions about what metrics to rollup and on what interval.  E.g. The average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis.  This
-is limiting; if, at a future date, the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis _and partitioned by `host_name`_,
+is limiting, in the future if the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis and partitioned by `host_name`,

nodes.bodyText:
Hi @jrodewig this is the original doc:
https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/master/rollup-understanding-groups.html
I think:

There should no comma after "if".
"host_name" format is not correct.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@ experimental[]
 
 To preserve flexibility, Rollup Jobs are defined based on how future queries may need to use the data.  Traditionally, systems force
 the admin to make decisions about what metrics to rollup and on what interval.  E.g. The average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis.  This
-is limiting; if, at a future date, the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis _and partitioned by `host_name`_,
+is limiting, in the future if the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis and partitioned by `host_name`,

nodes.bodyText:
Thanks for the clarification. Here's a suggestion that fixes the formatting without removing the semicolon.

        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            is limiting, in the future if the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis and partitioned by `host_name`,
          
          
            
            is limiting; if, in the future, the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis _and_ partitioned by `host_name`,

 To preserve flexibility, Rollup Jobs are defined based on how future queries may need to use the data.  Traditionally, systems force
 the admin to make decisions about what metrics to rollup and on what interval.  E.g. The average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis.  This
-is limiting; if, at a future date, the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis _and partitioned by `host_name`_,
+is limiting, in the future if the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis and partitioned by `host_name`,

nodes.bodyText: Hi @jrodewig thanks for the suggestion. I have updated the change.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@ experimental[]
 
 To preserve flexibility, Rollup Jobs are defined based on how future queries may need to use the data.  Traditionally, systems force
 the admin to make decisions about what metrics to rollup and on what interval.  E.g. The average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis.  This
-is limiting; if, at a future date, the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis _and partitioned by `host_name`_,
+is limiting, in the future if the admin wishes to see the average of `cpu_time` on an hourly basis and partitioned by `host_name`,
